Award.AwardTitle: Modeling, Identification, and Control towards Adaptive Personalized Glucose Management for Insulin-Deficient Diabetes

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop modeling and control algorithms for personalized adaptive insulin therapy. The algorithms can be used in the artificial pancreas for type-1 diabetes, but also would be useful for glucose management for insulin-dependent type-2 diabetes. This research will characterize patient-specific glucose dynamics by data-driven models with time-varying parameters that can be adjusted for the effects of food intake, physical activity and emotional tone under natural living conditions. This research will also develop adaptive control algorithms that enable a better control of hyperglycemia and prevention of hypoglycemia. Robustness issues will be addressed with respect to uncertainties in estimation of carb content, uncertain time-delay of meal intake, and variations in insulin and carb sensitivities. Deliverables include easy-to-implement real-time parameter estimation algorithms for insulin-glucose kinetics, adaptive control algorithms for insulin delivery, evaluation and validation via a FDA-approved simulator for type-1 diabetes, documentation of research results, and engineering student education.

If successful, the results of this research will facilitate the development of a mechanical artificial pancreas by means of providing a control algorithm used to close the loop between glucose sensing and insulin delivery in the artificial pancreas. Patients with type-1 or type-2 diabetes will benefit from the results of this research by lowering the risk of many of the devastating long-term complications. After testing and evaluation through FDA-approved simulation platforms, the results are transformable to be used in insulin pumps for clinical tests. Engineering students will get involved in this research through senior design projects as well as projects in undergraduate- and graduate-level control courses, e.g., design of user-friendly tools in aiding the control of diet and improvement of control algorithms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Existing models for glucose-insulin kinetics did not adequately characterize a patient under natural living conditions which involve meals and physical activities. Moreover, recent research indicated the need for personalized modeling and therapy to account for significant variability across individuals and variability within an individual at different times of the day. This project aimed to develop models for glucose dynamics and control algorithms for insulin delivery, which can be used under the context of Artificial Pancreas, to meet the time-varying adaptation requirement within an individual patient under natural living conditions, and the patient-specific adaption requirement to account for individual’s physiology and behavior.

 

Intellectual Merit: Outcomes from this project include: 1) We have characterized the patient-specific insulin-meal-glucose dynamics by data-driven models with time-varying parameters that can be adjusted to account for uncertainties under natural living conditions. Such models have been evaluated using both the FDA-approved UVa/Padova simulator and patient data. 2) We have developed a model predictive controller based on our patient-specific time-varying model and evaluate it using the FDA-approved simulator. 3) We have developed a variable-state-dimension algorithm that can detect unannounced meals and estimate meal sizes to achieve a robust glucose control in absence of meal information. Such algorithm has been evaluated using both the simulator and patient data. 4) We have developed patient-specific data-driven nonlinear models on glucose dynamics, accounting for the effects of physical activity (PA) in addition to the insulin and meal intake. In silico studies have demonstrated that such models are capable of capturing the immediate and prolonged PA effects on glucose. Broader Impact:  Results from this project could have significant impact on the glucose management for type 1 diabetic patients via Artificial Pancreas to improve their health and life quality. In this project, the collaboration of engineers on signal processing, modeling, and control systems design and health care providers for type 1 diabetes has helped to train graduate students to gain multi-disciplinary expertise and become part of a multi-disciplinary research workforce.
